issue.title: How to create a standalone meson executable?
issue.body: I'm looking if there's any way to create a standalone meson executable that doesn't depend on a python interpreter being installed. Platform is linux. I'm only seeing instructions about creating a zipapp.

issue.title: How to create a standalone meson executable?
issue.body: I'm looking if there's any way to create a standalone meson executable that doesn't depend on a python interpreter being installed. Platform is linux. I'm only seeing instructions about creating a zipapp.

comment.body: Thanks. Running `pyinstaller meson.py --additional-hooks-dir=packaging` from repo root creates meson binary at `dist/meson`

issue.title: How to create a standalone meson executable?
issue.body: I'm looking if there's any way to create a standalone meson executable that doesn't depend on a python interpreter being installed. Platform is linux. I'm only seeing instructions about creating a zipapp.

comment.body:
If you are familiar with using pyinstaller, that's what we use to build the Windows and macOS standalone installers.

We don't officially publish installers for Linux, but you can build your own. Pyinstaller will work fine on Linux too. This is how I debug the Windows installer, in fact. :)

The important thing is `--additional-hooks-dir=packaging` (and passing `meson.py` as the file to get packaged up).

issue.title: find_library with argument beginning in "lib" is a bad idea, warn about it
issue.body:
We need to support cases where the library might be called "foo.so" and therefore we check for exact matches too. But this also allows `cc.find_library('libfoo')` to find libfoo.so, which is strange and won't work in many cases. Emit a warning when this happens.

Fixes #10838

comment.body: @eli-schwartz So if I use `meson.get_compiler('cpp').find_library('libc++')` to determine the libc++ is available, `meson.get_compiler('cpp').find_library('c++')` may be more recommended under this cicumstance?

issue.title: How to create a standalone meson executable?
issue.body: I'm looking if there's any way to create a standalone meson executable that doesn't depend on a python interpreter being installed. Platform is linux. I'm only seeing instructions about creating a zipapp.

issue.title: Dependency between two custom_target
issue.body:
Hello,
I am having the hardest time with making dependency between two custom_target build. I am using meson with visual studio, so basically every custom_target is making visual studio project which will be build only when I launch VS solution and manually build it. 
What I am trying to achieve is generating a file with one custom_target - that I am able to do already - and copy that file to different subproject, which will need it. so let's say that I have those two custom_target(s):
```meson
some_file = custom_target('some_file',
	output : 'new_file.txt',
    input : ['old_file.txt],
    command : [python, some_python_program],
    install : true,
    install_dir : get_option('bindir'),
    )

custom_target('some_file2',
	output : 'new_file.txt',
	input : 'new_file.txt',
	command : [configure_file(input : 'new_file.txt',, output : 'subprojects/some_path/build/', copy: true)],
	depends: some_file,
	)
```
so as you can see I put some_file - which is returned object from first custom_target to second custom_target dependency but what I got is "Input can only be strings or file objects".

The only thing I could print from some_file object is full_path() which I can't use in input or output because at this point this file doesn't exist. What am I missing here? also I couldn't use indexes, like some_file[0] or some_file[1] - all what I got are exceptions.

Is something not working, or am I not understanding it at all?

comment.body:
I'm opening up an issue relating to custom_target and executable/library dependencies now but just let me leave a comment to clean up confusion: dependencies between custom_targets doesn't work *by design* according to [this bit](https://mesonbuild.com/Custom-build-targets.html#details-on-command-invocation) of the documentation. The issue I'm posting now does not refute this decision - so as far as I know everyone coming here looking for a solution to chain custom_targets and make a custom_target pipeline:

The "correct" way to make a custom_target pipeline
========================================
You have two choices:
1. Make a single custom_target that calls a script.
2. Create multiple build files which each declare_dependency and create a dependency chain between them.

Do whatever feels cleaner for your project.

issue.title: itstool.py: Prepend call to itstool with sys.executable
issue.body:
Hi,

This PR attempts to make calling `itstool` work on environments where shebang lines are not directly supported, by prepending the `itstool` call with `sys.executable`.

This was found while attempting to add `clang-cl` build support for appstream.

With blessings, thank you!

comment.body:
Hi @eli-schwartz,

Thanks a bunch, issue is open at pypa/pip#12375.

pull_request.title: docs/dependency: fix type of version kwarg
pull_request.body: In the description both types are used.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,7 +39,9 @@ assert(fs.expanduser('~/foo').endswith('foo'), 'expanduser with tail failed')
 # -- as_posix
 assert(fs.as_posix('/') == '/', 'as_posix idempotent')
 assert(fs.as_posix('\\') == '/', 'as_posix simple')
-assert(fs.as_posix('\\\\') == '/', 'as_posix simple')
+# Python 3.12 changed how these paths are handled, so deal with both.
+drivepath = fs.as_posix('\\\\')
+assert(drivepath == '/' or drivepath == '//', 'as_posix simple')
comment.body: If this needs further changes then I'll change it. If this goes green I'll release as-is because it is already overdue. In that case patches welcome.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,7 +39,9 @@ assert(fs.expanduser('~/foo').endswith('foo'), 'expanduser with tail failed')
 # -- as_posix
 assert(fs.as_posix('/') == '/', 'as_posix idempotent')
 assert(fs.as_posix('\\') == '/', 'as_posix simple')
-assert(fs.as_posix('\\\\') == '/', 'as_posix simple')
+# Python 3.12 changed how these paths are handled, so deal with both.
+drivepath = fs.as_posix('\\\\')
+assert(drivepath == '/' or drivepath == '//', 'as_posix simple')
comment.body: maybe we should change the text of the message to make it different from the message of the previous assertion.

issue.title: add devenv to introspection data
issue.body:
This is to allow external tools to run executables using meson devenv,
without the need of wrapping it with the meson command.

comment.body:
> I'm opposed to this. External tools should load the data as written by `meson devenv --dump`.

This is the same data, just a different format. My usecase is that I already use introspection data to build a complexe solution and project files for VisualStudio, but I'm missing the information for setting the correct PATH when running executables with the debugger. I could call `meson devenv --dump` or wrap the executable with the `meson devenv` command, but it would be much simpler for me to simply get it from the introspection files, just like all other information I need for this task.

pull_request.title: Add relative path support for native/crossfiles
pull_request.body:
As indicated in #3439 some project setups have the toolchain included within the repository. To reduce the initial starting effort when a developer clones/checkouts the repository this PR adds support for binaries with a relative path within native/crossfile.

Fixes #3439

issue.title: Add relative path support for native/crossfiles
issue.body:
As indicated in #3439 some project setups have the toolchain included within the repository. To reduce the initial starting effort when a developer clones/checkouts the repository this PR adds support for binaries with a relative path within native/crossfile.

Fixes #3439

issue.title: add devenv to introspection data
issue.body:
This is to allow external tools to run executables using meson devenv,
without the need of wrapping it with the meson command.

comment.body: I'm opposed to this. External tools should load the data as written by `meson devenv --dump`.

commits.message: Handle path behaviour change in Python 3.12.

pull_request.body:
This is to allow external tools to run executables using meson devenv,
without the need of wrapping it with the meson command.

issue.title: docs/...Wrap-manual.md: explain clone-recursive
issue.body: Explain the exact usage, especially the type (was previously only mentioned in the release notes and the code).

comment.body:
> None of the settings contain type statements they are usually inferred from "name of XXX" as a string.

Most of them are self explaining: `depth` obviously needs an `int`, `url` a `string`.

> There are more boolean "true" types than just this -- the patch makes the docs inconsistent. (It's also repetitive.)

Meson accepts just `value.lower() == 'true'`. In the wrap documentation no other bool value occurs.

2. Try to build [gnome-desktop](https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-desktop/tree/master)
3. Wait for the error

I expected for the build to run normally
